user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_add_to_fd_set_:
```c
int
MHD_add_to_fd_set_ (MHD_socket fd,
                    fd_set *set,
                    MHD_socket *max_fd,
                    int fd_setsize)
{
  if ( (NULL == set) ||
       (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET == fd) )
    return 0;

#ifndef HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE
  (void) fd_setsize;  /* Mute compiler warning */
  fd_setsize = (int) FD_SETSIZE; /* Help compiler to optimise */
#endif /* ! HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE */

  if (! MHD_SCKT_FD_FITS_FDSET_SETSIZE_ (fd,
                                         set,
                                         fd_setsize))
    return 0;
  MHD_SCKT_ADD_FD_TO_FDSET_SETSIZE_ (fd,
                                     set,
                                     fd_setsize);
  if ( (NULL != max_fd) &&
       ( (fd > *max_fd) ||
         (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET == *max_fd) ) )
    *max_fd = fd;
  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (! MHD_SCKT_FD_FITS_FDSET_SETSIZE_ (fd,
                                         set,
                                         fd_setsize))
    return 0;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment calls MHD_SCKT_FD_FITS_FDSET_SETSIZE_ to check whether fd fits into the fd_set and does not invoke any <string.h> functions itself. Rule 21.17 concerns use of memcpy/memmove/memset/strlen/etc.; this fragment does not call those. (A possible violation would occur only if the called macro/function internally used a string.h routine that could access beyond the bounds of 'set' or used an incorrect size when manipulating the fd_set.)
